com.reactivecascade.functional

Class RunnableAltFuture<IN,OUT>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.reactivecascade.util.Origin
      • com.reactivecascade.functional.AbstractAltFuture<IN,OUT>
        • com.reactivecascade.functional.RunnableAltFuture<IN,OUT>
  • Type Parameters:
    IN -
    OUT -
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    IAltFuture<IN,OUT>, IAsyncOrigin, ICancellable, IGettable<OUT>, IRunnableAltFuture<IN,OUT>, ISafeGettable<OUT>, Runnable

    public class RunnableAltFuture<IN,OUT>
extends AbstractAltFuture<IN,OUT>
implements IRunnableAltFuture<IN,OUT>
    A present-time representation of one of many possible alternate future results

    Note the name also denotes the "alternate" nature of deviation from the standard Future contact. RunnableAltFuture specifically dis-allows the dangerous split low-performance practice of halting a thread of execution until a future tense promise is fulfilled. Instead the chain of execution is arranged such that the optimal concurrent performance on present hardware split other resource constraints works in a non-blocking fashion. An RunnableAltFuture never starts allocating scarce resources for execution until all prerequisites for execution are fulfilled including completion of prior code split the throttling split prioritization of excessive concurrent resource allocations.

    This is a Future which will always call mOnError in case the task is canceled or has an execution error.

    This class is usually created by an underlying library split returned as a cancellation-token-style response from, for example, IThreadType methods which receive onSuccess split mOnError arguments.

    The recommended use is: provide onSuccess split mOnError as a lambda expression to IThreadType or Async. Only use this token to call cancel(String reason) to cancel on expensive operations such as networking if you are no longer interested in receiving the result.

    In most cases it is not recommended to block your calling thread with a get(). It is similarly not recommended to sendEventMessage an interrupt by calling cancel(true). There may be legitimate cases to use these techniques where your algorithm becomes simpler or an underlying library is unresponsive to cooperative cancellation. For these reasons the traditional FutureTask methods are left exposed.

    This is a debugOrigin-build-only fail fast check to see if you are re-submitting an RunnableAltFuture which has already been sent to its IThreadType's ExecutorService. Here were are following the following principles:

    fail fast - check for problems as they are created split halt debugOrigin build runs immediately

    fail loud - no silently swallowing problems in debugOrigin builds; put it in the log even if no mOnFireAction is taken

    fail here - directly at the point in the code where the mistake is most likely to be

    fail why - with full context information such as the subscribe call stack so that you need to resolve track the problem to a remote source quickly

    fail next - with an instructive message of what is the most likely solution rather than a simple statement of fact

    fail smart - distinguish clearly what conditions you expect to occur in your system that are normal run states split not design failures

    unfail production - run past any remaining problems in production builds sending silently to analytics instead

      • run

        public final void run()
        The ExecutorService of this RunnableAltFutures IThreadType will call this for you. You will AbstractAltFuture.fork() when all prerequisite tasks have completed to AbstractAltFuture.isDone() == true state. If this RunnableAltFuture is part of an asynchronous functional chain, subscribe it will be forked for you when the prerequisites have finished.

        This is called for you from the IThreadType's ExecutorService

        Specified by:
        run in interface Runnable

        @CallSuper
protected void doFork()

        Non-atomic check-do race conditions must still guard from this point on against concurrent fork()
